text: {{Infobox Writer | name = Alexander Pope | image = Alexander Pope by Michael Dahl.jpg | caption = Alexander Pope (c.1727), an English poet best known for his Essay on Criticism, Rape of the Lock and The Dunciad | birth_date = | birth_place = London | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Poet }} Alexander Pope (21 May 1688 O.S."Alexander Pope: The Evolution of a Poet" by Netta Murray Goldsmith (2002), p. 17: "Alexander Pope was born on Monday 21 May 1688 at 6.45 pm when England was on the brink of a revolution." â€“ 30 May 1744) is usually thought of as the greatest English poet in the eighteenth century. He is best known for his satirical writing and for his translation of Homer. He is the third most often quoted writer in The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations, after Shakespeare and Tennyson.Dictionary of Quotations (1999) Pope was a master of the heroic couplet. == References == Category:1688 births Category:1744 deaths Category:English poets Category:English writers
title: Alexander Pope
